E G in vertical Angle A C B may conveniently be about 60 degrees 
M N designeth the Lens its breadth 2 1/2 or 3 inches S F one of the streight 
lynes in wch difforme Rays may be conserved to flow Successively from the 
Sun F P and F R two of those Rays unequally refracted which the Lens 
make to converge towards Q and after discussation to diverge againe 
and H I the paper at divers distances on which the colours are projected 
wch in Q constitute whiteness but are Red and yellow in R r and s and 
blew and Purple in O p and u
If you proceed further to try the Imposibility of changeing any 
uncompounded colour (wch I haue incerted in the 3d & 13 propositions) tis 
requisite yt ye roome be made very darke lest any scattering light mixing 
wth the colour disturb and allay it & render it compound contrary to ye 
designe of the experiment Tis also requisite that there be a perfecter 
separation of the colours then after the manner aboue described can be 
made by ye refraction of the single prisme and how to make such further
separac[i]ions will scarse be difficult to them that consider the discouered Laws of 
Refractions But if triall shalbe made wth colours not throughly seperated 
there must be allowed changes proportionably to the mixture Thus if 
compound yellow light fall upon Blew Bise, the Bise will not appeare 
perfectly yellow but rather Greene because there are in the yellow mixture 
many rays indued wth Greene and Greene being lesse remote from ye usual blew 
colour of Bise then yellow is the more copiously reflected by it 
In like manner if any one of the prismatick colours suppose Red be 
intercepted on designe to try ye asserted imposibility of reproduceing yt colour 
out of the others wch are pretermitted, tis ne[ce]ssary either yt ye colours be very 
well parted before the Red be intercepted or that together wth the red the 
neighbouring=colours into which any red is secretly dispersed (that is the 
yellow and perhapes greene too) be intercepted or elce that allowance be 
made for the emerging so much red out of the yellow Green as may posibly 
haue been diffused and scatteringly blended in those colours And if these 
things be observed the new production of red or any intercepted colour 
will be found impossible 
This I conceive is enough for an Introduction to Experiments of this 
kind which if any of the R Society shall be so curious as to prosecute I 
shall be very glade to be informed with wt success: That if any thing Seeme 
to be defective, or to thwart this relation I may haue an opportunity of 
giveing further direction about it or of acknowledging my errors if I 
haue comitted any.
<s>So for this learned and very ingenious letter, which haueing been by that 
Illustrious Company before whom it was read with much applause com[m]itted 
to the consideration of some of the Fellows well versed in those Arguments 
of reader[?] may possibly in another tract be informed of some report given 
ther[e?] upon this discourse <\s>
